More Notes: Temperature increase reduces efficiency; range given is impact per degree Celsius; value is midpoint with half the range as SD.
Desert regions experience up to a 60% reduction in electricity output due to atmospheric conditions like clouds, aerosols, pollutants, and dust.

Real-world power delivery can deviate by up to 10% from Standard Test Conditions (STC) due to temperature and other environmental factors; using 2025 as the publication year.

Efficiency loss due to temperature is quantified by temperature coefficient of power; using 0 as an indicator that a negative temperature coefficient means efficiency goes down with increasing temperature; 2025 as the publication year.
This value indicates a reduction in solar power capacity due to the solar eclipse on August 21, 2017, affecting nearly 22 GW of total generating capacity at the time.
This value indicates a reduction in solar power capacity due to the solar eclipse on April 8, 2024, affecting over three times more capacity compared to 2017.
Represents the drop in state-wide solar PV production during the 2017 eclipse, from 7.2 GW to 1.5 GW over 40 minutes.
Global horizontal irradiance reduction greater than 0% from 1960 to 2000 due to climate change. Using 0.1 as a placeholder.
Solar irradiance decreased on cloudy days between 1964 and 1990 by 8% per decade.
Atmospheric water vapor concentration increased by 7% for every degree of warming since the late 19th century.
